citations.narrative:
In review of the water quality records, weekly coliform testing was not recorded between 12/20-12/29 and 1/30-2/8. In
each of these cases the water samples were not taken and tested weekly for coliform counts as required by the
regulation. During the first period, the facility was notified at the last minute of a holiday closure of the laboratory, and did
not have alternative means to complete the required weekly water quality testing. Marine mammal facilities must take and
test water samples weekly for coliforms and maintain the records for review during inspection.
Correct for all future inspections.

On February 8th, 2023 Pip the Harbor Seal was restrained for medical procedures and moved into back holding after not
eating for 3+ days. On that day, the medical note includes "releasing back into exhibit is not an option at this time due to
high coliforms at Seal Cove." Pip continued to receive medical care and was still in back holding at the time of inspection,
five weeks later. The holding enclosure includes a water tank that has a depth of 2 feet, which does not meet space
standards under 3.104, which requires a minimum of 3 feet of water depth.
The Attending Veterinarian (AV) documented medical treatment on an almost daily basis initially and tapering off as Pip
improved. The AV did not justify in writing on a weekly basis the extension of medical holding not meeting space
requirements beyond two weeks as required in the Animal Welfare Regulations. On 12 March 2023, the medical note
indicates "If able, recheck blood. If improves, consider d/c cefpodoxime and as she is working well outside of the house,
consider letting Pip out on exhibit." Starting on the 22nd of February, then on the 1st, 8th, and 15th of March continued
medical holding not meeting space standards should have been noted in the animals record with justification by the AV.
Correct from this day forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with animal care staff.
Additional Inspectors:
William Campbell, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICEREnd Section

narrative:
3.106(b)(3) 
   
Water quality. 
In review of the water quality records, weekly coliform testing was not recorded between 12/20-12/29 and 1/30-2/8. In 
each of these cases the water samples were not taken and tested weekly for coliform counts as required by the 
regulation. During the first period, the facility was notified at the last minute of a holiday closure of the laboratory, and did 
not have alternative means to complete the required weekly water quality testing.  Marine mammal facilities must take and 
test water samples weekly for coliforms and maintain the records for review during inspection. 
 
Correct for all future inspections. 
3.110(b) 
   
Veterinary care. 
On February 8th, 2023 Pip the Harbor Seal was restrained for medical procedures and moved into back holding after not 
eating for 3+ days. On that day, the medical note includes "releasing back into exhibit is not an option at this time due to 
high coliforms at Seal Cove." Pip continued to receive medical care and was still in back holding at the time of inspection, 
five weeks later. The holding enclosure includes a water tank that has a depth of 2 feet, which does not meet space 
standards under 3.104, which requires a minimum of 3 feet of water depth.

The Attending Veterinarian (AV) documented medical treatment on an almost daily basis initially and tapering off as Pip 
improved. The AV did not justify in writing on a weekly basis the extension of medical holding not meeting space 
requirements beyond two weeks as required in the Animal Welfare Regulations.  On 12 March 2023, the medical note 
indicates "If able, recheck blood. If improves, consider d/c cefpodoxime and as she is working well outside of the house, 
consider letting Pip out on exhibit." Starting on the 22nd of February, then on the 1st, 8th, and 15th of March continued 
medical holding not meeting space standards should have been noted in the animals record with justification by the AV. 
 
Correct from this day forward. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with animal care staff. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
William Campbell, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICEREnd Section
